Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Particle Physics at the Collider and Cosmic Ray Energy Frontiers
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides support for the University of Kansas Particle Physics group to conduct research with the CMS experiment at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland and to complete ongoing efforts in Particle Astrophysics at several locations worldwide. The group is making significant contributions to CMS both analytically and technically. In analysis, the group is focusing its efforts on studies of Higgs bosons, top quarks, electroweak processes and new phenomena. Technical contributions include responsibilities for supporting the existing CMS tracker and the building the new "Phase I" pixel detector. Toward a future high energy electron collider, the group is developing improved methods of jet energy reconstruction using particle-flow based techniques. In the area of particle astrophysics, the group is completing a number of technically challenging efforts based upon radio detection and located in Antarctica, Utah and Siberia. In the area of broader impacts, the group has an exceptionally strong outreach program including a QuarkNet Center, the Quarked! Project that engages young children in the excitement of science and scientific questions, and significant engagement of undergraduates at all levels of the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report NSF

Grant 1306953 (KUCR 70543)

               NSF grant 1306953 supported the activities of the University of Kansas (KU) experimental particle physics group from September 1, 2013 until August 31, 2017. Most of the funds went to salary support for the group, which includes three faculty members, three postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, undergraduate students, and summer high school researchers. The remainder of the funds provided supplies and travel support for the group. The group works in collaboration with the CMS experiment at CERN’s Large Hadron Collider. This is a multipurpose experiment that records data from collisions between two high energy protons. The group was also involved in the development of detectors for a future electron-positron linear collider and has public outreach projects.

               The intellectual merit of the proposal comes from the potential to provide a greater understanding of matter and energy at the smallest distance scales and so address some of the most fundamental questions in science. The CMS detector was one of two experiments that discovered the Higgs boson in 2012. This completed the roster of particles in the theory known as the Standard Model. The Higgs boson provides mass to the other particles and KU’s data analysis efforts have focused on this particle and its relation to the heaviest known elementary particle – the top quark. There are numerous phenomena that the Standard Model does not explain, so we are working toward discoveries that will take us beyond this theoretical framework.

              CMS began taking data in late 2009 and has taken data at several different collision energies: 7 TeV, 8 TeV and most recently 13 TeV. KU graduate student Danny Noonan completed his Ph.D. and published two papers on the production of the top quark together with the W boson, which is one of the particles that conveys the weak nuclear force. Evidence for this process was found in the 7 TeV data and a statistically significant discovery of this process was made with the 8 TeV data. Data analysis with the 13 TeV data is ongoing and has focused on searches for new particles, especially heavier cousins of the top quark (called “vector-like quarks”) that would decay into a top quark and a Higgs boson. Results of a search using data from the first 13 TeV run were published and work continues with the latest data.

             KU helped to build and commission a new component of the CMS detector known as the pixel detector. This is the part of the detector that is closest to the proton beams and provides precise position measurements that allow us to locate the initial collision points and secondary decay points for particles. The group helped with the electronic readout system and the testing of the sensors. The group is now working on the development of a future version of this device. KU also used the nuclear interactions of particles with the detector material to make a sort of “X-ray” image of the detector. The goal was to confirm our understanding of where the material is located in the inner part of the CMS detector. A paper is in preparation that describes the technique that was used. Two KU undergraduates were key data analysts for this work.

              Linear collider work focused on ways to measure particle energies in the environment of a future electron-positron collider. KU participated in international studies of future detectors that would make precision measurements. The work involves developing improved methods of jet energy reconstruction using particle-flow based methods, in collaboration with colleagues in the ILD detector concept and CALICE groups.

              The broader impacts of this proposal come largely from our educational efforts that include the training of future scientists by mentoring and providing research opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, high school and postdoctoral students. The Quarked!TM project was an important outreach focus. A major goal of this project to get grade school children excited about science by presenting modern physics principles in an engaging way. The website (www.quarked.org) that was first launched in February 2006, was further developed and some of the educational games were made available as phone aps. KU students are the programmers for the website. KU has been a part of QuarkNet, a nationwide project to introduce particle physics into the high school classroom, since 2001. Each summer the KU center offers a workshop for area high school physics teachers and summer research experiences for area high school students. One of our faculty members, Alice Bean, served as a Jefferson Science Fellow working with the State Department for a year. She and other faculty have given public presentations on science in our community.
